Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary 2018



Georgia-Pacific's Palatka Mill is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for the mill workers, the general public, contractors, and the environment. As part of this commitment, the company has established a system to help ensure the safe operation of the chemical processes at this facility. One component of this system is a Risk Management Program that helps manage the chemical process risks at the Palatka Mill and addresses compliance with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs. One of the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) describing the Risk Management Program at our Palatka Mill. This document is intended to provide the public with a description of the Risk Management Program in use at the Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mill.



The Risk Management Program at the Palatka Mill consists of three core elements:



I. Hazard assessments which serve to help us understand the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases.



II. Prevention programs which serve to help maintain and safely operate the process which contains more than the threshold quantity of Chlorine Dioxide. 



III. Emergency response program which serves to help respond to accidental releases of Chlorine Dioxide from the covered process. 



Although the Risk Management Program at the Palatka Mill helps provide assurance that our mill is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the overall safety program. The Palatka Mill has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards that are designed to minimize the potential for the release of any hazardous substances. 



When hazardous substances are used at the mill, the equipment is carefully designed, built, and operat

ed to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release. Industry and government standards are closely adhered to in design, construction, and operation of the equipment.



The safety program at the Palatka Mill consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP Rule. This Executive Summary is primarily intended to describe those parts of the safety program at the Palatka Mill that are required by the RMP Rule.



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Palatka Mill is committed to the safety of workers and the public, as well as the preservation of the environment through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. The Palatka Mill implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. These controls include training programs for personnel, programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the processes, and programs to evaluate the hazards at the Palatka Mill.



In the event of an accidental release, the Palatka Mill will control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injury to the public and/or the environment. The Mill provides response training for upset conditions to facility personnel, designates an Emergency Response Compliance Standard Owner to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the local emergency response organizations. The Palatka Mill works with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will not occur in the event a release does occur.



In order to effectively implement these policies, The Palatka Mill has established a management system directed by the Vice President of the Palatka Mill. The Vice President has the overall responsibility for ensuring that the facility operates in a safe and reliable manner. This responsibility includes overseeing the elements of th

e Risk Management Program. To ensure that the Risk Management Program is appropriately managed, the Vice President has designated responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the EPA RMP elements and the elements of OSHA's PSM program as required under 40 CFR Part 68.15 and 29 CFR 1910.119 respectively to the Process Safety Manager and Safety Manager. The Process Safety Manager has the direct responsibility for Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Start Up Review, Incident Investigation, and Compliance Audits. The Safety Manager has the direct responsibility for Hot Work Permits, Contractors, and Emergency Response.



2. Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mill's Regulated Substances



Georgia-Pacific's Palatka Mill is a pulp and paper mill primarily involved in the manufacture of brown/bleached pulp and paper products. As part of this manufacturing process, the mill produces and stores Chlorine Dioxide for the use of bleaching pulp. The Chlorine Dioxide solution system, which includes the generation, storage and distribution of the Chlorine Dioxide, is considered a Program Level 3 RMP covered process.  



3. Accidental Release Prevention Program 



Georgia-Pacific's Palatka Mill has always used a prevention program to help prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances. Beginning in 1992, the Palatka Mill formalized this prevention program for the Chlorine Dioxide system to comply with the 14 elements of The United States Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119. In 1996, the EPA RMP Rule established that a Program Level 3 prevention program would become a requirement for these processes as well. The Palatka Mill's Program Level 3 Prevention Program under the RMP Rule is essentially the same as the OSHA PSM Program, except that the R

MP also focuses on protecting the public and the environment. The following sections briefly describe the twelve elements of the Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mill's Program Level 3 prevention program that addresses the EPA RMP rule prevention program requirements for the Chlorine Dioxide System.



* Process Safety Information (40 CFR 68.65):  The Palatka Mill maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure the safe operation of the process. These documents address the hazards of the chemicals used in the process, the technology data of the process, and the design basis and configurations of the equipment used in the process. The Palatka Mill ensures that this process safety information is maintained, accurate, and available to all the Palatka Mill employees, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). All of the information and documentation for the RMP Prevention Program is maintained in the Chemical Process Safety Office at the Palatka Mill. The Palatka Mill maintains the following chemical process safety information for each regulated substance in a covered process. 



i.   Toxicity information.

ii.  Permissible exposure limits.

iii. Physical data.

iv.  Reactivity data.

v.   Corrosivity data.

vi.  Thermal and chemical stability data.

vii. Hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of different materials that could occur.



The Palatka Mill uses safety data sheets (SDSs) to provide most of the process chemical information. Safety data sheets (SDS) document the physical and chemical properties of the hazardous substances handled at the mill, including non-regulated substances in the covered process. SDSs for hazardous substances handled in each process are available in a web based system. Every employee has access to our SDS system and has annual training on accessing SDSs.  In addition, SDSs are provided to the LEPC for use in helping formulate emergency response plans. Whenever required information, such as corrosivity data or haza

rdous effects of inadvertent mixing, is not available in SDSs, the mill develops the missing data from other sources and provides it in separate documents.



The Palatka Mill maintains the following required process technology information:



i.   Block flow or simplified process flow diagram.

ii.  Process chemistry.

iii. Maximum intended inventory.

iv.  Safe upper and lower limits for parameters such as temperature, pressure, flow, or composition.

v.   Evaluation of the consequences of deviations from established operating limits.



This information comes from the engineering design documents for the processes or was developed in conjunction with the PHA. 



The Palatka Mill also maintains the following information pertaining to equipment in the regulated processes:



i.    Materials of construction.

ii.   Piping and instrument diagrams (P&IDs).

iii.  Electrical classification.

iv.   Relief system design and design basis.

v.    Ventilation system design.

vi.   Design codes and standards employed.

vii.  Material and energy balances for processes built after 5/26/92.

viii. Safety systems (interlocks, detection, and/or suppression systems).



This information comes from the engineering design documents for the processes or was developed in conjunction with the PHA.  Whenever required information was not available, the Palatka Mill obtained the information from equipment vendors and plant engineering. In conjunction with the equipment information collection efforts, the Palatka Mill documented that the equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.



Many of the operating parameters are included in the technology information to help with the safe operation of the process. These documents are also used to train employees, to perform process hazard analyses, and to help maintain the equipment to the design specification.



* Process Hazard Analysis (40 CFR 68.67):  The Palatka Mill performs and periodically updates

process hazard analyses (PHAs) of the covered process to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process. A team composed of personnel with engineering and process operating experience, and a team leader with experience in performing process hazard analyses, is assembled to analyze the process. The Palatka Mill primarily uses the "Hazard and Operability" (HAZOP) technique and supplemental checklists, to perform this analysis. The PHA team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including recommendations. The Palatka Mill ensures that all recommendations from the PHAs are resolved appropriately, and the mill ensures that information from the PHAs (including recommended resolutions) is communicated to all potentially affected employees.



* Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.69): The Palatka Mill operators, supervisors, and engineers work together to develop and maintain accurate operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and upset operating conditions. The operating procedures include:



i.   Initial start-up.

ii.  Normal operations.

iii. Temporary operations.

iv.  Emergency shutdown, including the conditions under which emergency shutdown is required and assignment of shutdown responsibility to qualified operators to ensure that emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner.

v.   Emergency operations.

vi.  Normal shutdown.

vii. Start-up following a turnaround or an emergency shutdown.



The Palatka Mill uses PSI information from process designers, equipment manufacturers, and their own experience to create and validate the procedures.



The procedures address the following information:



i.   Steps for safely conducting activities.

ii.  Safe operating limits

.

iii. Consequences of process deviations, as well as steps required to correct or avoid such deviations.

iv.  Safety and health considerations including, properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process, precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment, control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs, quality control for raw materials and control of regulated substance inventory levels, and any special or unique hazards.

v.   Safety systems and their functions.



The Palatka Mill has a formal review process to approve procedures and changes to procedures. Furthermore, the Palatka Mill annually reviews existing procedures, makes any needed revisions, and certifies the procedures as current and accurate. The Palatka Mill keeps procedures in locations that are readily accessible to employees who may need access to the information.



In addition to the process-specific procedures, the Palatka Mill also develops and maintains more widely applicable safe work practices addressing issues such as lockout/tag out, confined space entry, line breaking, and control over entry to processes. These safe work practices apply to all employees and contractors.

 

* Training (40 CFR 68.71): The Palatka Mill trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. The mill's training program for process operators includes both the initial training and refresher training that covers a general overview of the process, the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. Computer based testing, qualification, and oral reviews are used to verify that the employees understand the training materials before the employee can operate the process.



The operators are consulted about the frequency of the training and the materials to be used for

the training. Recommendations from the operators are reviewed and changes to the training are implemented as appropriate.



* Mechanical Integrity (40 CFR 68.73):  The Palatka Mill maintains the mechanical integrity of the covered process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. The Palatka Mill's mechanical integrity program includes an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails and a quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meets the design standards required for service in our covered processes. The Palatka Mill's mechanical integrity program also includes:



i. Specifications for inspection and testing of process equipment.

ii. Specifications for replacement parts and equipment.

iii. Standard maintenance procedures for inspecting, testing, and maintaining process equipment.

iv. Procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tag out, hot work, and confined space entry.

v. Training of maintenance personnel.

vi. Documentation of maintenance activity.



* Management of Change (40 CFR 68.75):  The Palatka Mills management of change program includes the process for evaluating and approving all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind are allowed without completing a management of change form. All other changes must be confirmed through the full management of change program to help ensure that inadvertent consequences of the process changes are prevented, safety consequences of the changes are addressed, affected process safety information and operating procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.



* Pre-startup Safety Reviews: (40 CFR 68.77):  The Palatka Mill performs a safety review o

f new or modified equipment in the covered process before the process is placed into service to help ensure that the process has been prepared to operate safely. This review confirms that:



i. Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

ii. Adequate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place.

iii. Employee training has been completed.

iv. For a covered process, a PHA has been performed if the process is new or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified.



A pre-startup safety review is completed as part of the management of change process, is documented, and ensures that the appropriate items have been addressed.



* Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.79):   The Palatka Mill or the Georgia-Pacific Global Health and Safety Group audits the covered processes annually to be certain that the mill's prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations. The Palatka Mill or the Global Health and Safety Group assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the RMP Rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP Rule and also whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.



* Incident Investigations (40 CFR 68.81):  The Palatka Mill investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented. The mill trains employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An incident investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. A root cause analysis is performed for all incidents. The results of the inves

tigations are documented, recommendations are resolved and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.



* Employee Participation (40 CFR 68.83): The Palatka Mill has developed a written employee participation program for the covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of the Palatka Mill employees are addressed. The mill encourages active participation from personnel in the development and maintenance of the prevention program activities of all processes at the mill. Employees are consulted on, and informed about, all aspects of the RMP Rule prevention program, including the development of Process Hazard Analysis and Operating Procedures.



* Hot Work Permits (40 CFR 68.85):  The Palatka Mill complies with requirements of the Georgia-Pacific Hot Work Compliance Standard to ensure that the site mitigates the risks to personnel and facilities and reduces the chance of incidents while performing work activities.  The vehicle for this risk reduction is a Hot Work permitting system that requires conscious forethought to hazard potential prior to starting this type of work and ensuring that the risks are minimized / eliminated. Personnel who are to perform hot work are required to fill out the Hot Work Permit form. The supervisor reviews the completed form before work can begin.



* Contractors (40 CFR 68.87): The Palatka Mill has a detailed contractor safety program that applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to an RMP covered process. This program does not apply to contractors providing incidental services that do not influence process safety.



The Palatka Mill selects contractors based on prior site work history and on information that they are required to provide as part of the bid process. The bid information includes their current safety programs (i.e., safety organization, employee education and training, and accident prevention program) and their prior safety

performance (i.e., OSHA injury rates, property loss experience, regulatory compliance history, and worker's compensation insurance experience). Bidders that do not provide all of the requested information, that do not have the desired skills, or that have an unsatisfactory safety record are dropped from further consideration. Contractors that meet the minimum safety requirements are then judged to determine which one can provide a quality job at the lowest cost. If a contractor currently working in the plant is under consideration, the facility reviews recent safety audits and contacts plant personnel on the job site to verify satisfactory job performance before the facility authorizes the purchase order.



The Palatka Mill requires all contractors to complete a computer based training program that highlights the most hazardous areas in the mill.  The training includes the mill's safe work practices, and the emergency response procedures for the mill. The mill provides SDSs for the hazardous materials that may affect the contractor work area, copies of plant safe work practices and policies, and emergency response actions associated with the contractor's work. The mill then introduces personnel with whom they will communicate.

The Palatka Mill requires contractors to perform the following tasks to help ensure process safety:



i. Train each of their employees in the work practices necessary to safely perform the contracted work.

ii. Train each of their employees on the plant's safe work practices.

iii. Document that each of their employees has received and understands the training. 

iv. Ensure that each of their employees follows the plant safety rules and safe work practices.

v. Report to the facility's staff any hazards created or found by their employees at the job site.

vi. Provide access and responses to the facility's personnel who may appear at the job site to evaluate contractor safety performance.

vii. Provide information on contract employee job

site injuries/illnesses to the facility's designated representative.



The Palatka Mills Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Chlorine Dioxide is produced at the mill and stored as a diluted aqueous solution to avoid the necessity of transporting large quantities of the solution. Chlorine dioxide is produced in the chlorine dioxide generator and piped to an absorption tower, where as high as 14 gram-per-liter (1.4% by weight) strength in solution is absorbed. In addition to the required RMP prevention program elements, the Palatka Mill has implemented safety features specific to the Chlorine Dioxide System. The Chlorine Dioxide System in use at the Palatka mill has a series of safety interlocks that ensure the smooth operation of the generator and that it runs smoothly to prevent rapid decomposition.  



4. Five-Year Accident History



There was one incident that met the Five-Year Accidental History at the time of last resubmission.  This incident occurred March 5, 2017.  Short and long term corrective actions were put in place.  All other incident requirements per the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Regulation 40 CFR Part 68.6 were completed.



5. Emergency Response Programs



Georgia-Pacific Palatka Operations has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. The emergency response plan includes procedures or directions to procedures for:



i.  Informing the local response organizations and the public about accidental releases that could reasonably result in offsite consequences.

ii. Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accidental human exposure to hazardous substances at the mill.

iii. Controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances. 

iv. Inspecting and maintaining emergency response equipment.

v.  Reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.



The Palatka Mill maintains an emergency medical res

ponse team trained in emergency response procedures. All the mill personnel are trained in evacuation procedures. The Palatka Mill periodically conducts emergency response drills, including drills coordinated with the local fire department.



The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations and has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the Local Emergency Planning Committee. The Palatka Mill maintains a regular dialogue with the local emergency response organizations and provides appropriate information to them.



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Georgia-Pacific's Palatka Mill continuously strives for safety excellence.  Studies associated with prevention program elements such as Process Hazard Analyses, Incident Investigations, Management of Change, and Compliance Audits are regularly conducted at Georgia-Pacific's Palatka Mill to verify designs, safeguards, identify potential hazards, and mitigate risk.  Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, employee suggestions, or other types of risk assessments.  Recommendations are reviewed and as appropriate, corresponding action items are developed to implement the recommendations.
